text: see this guy do you think our inverted
friend here is happy sad angry or what
you've got three seconds to decide
time's up
turns out he's hideous but you couldn't
tell while he was hanging like a bat so
why can't we read people's expressions
upside down what's happening here is
called the Thatcher effect and it says a
lot about how we recognize facial
expressions or whatever that is the
Thatcher effect is named after you
guessed it Margaret Thatcher whose
picture was first used to demonstrate
the phenomenon the Thatcher effect plays
on our expectation of what facial
expressions should look like relative to
the rest of the face it works like this
we signify our emotions with our eyes
and mouth
the superior temporal sulcus section of
our brain is in charge of recognising
these facial expressions and emotions
but our brain has almost no experience
seeing facial expressions upside down it
desperately wants to see eyes and mouths
normally even if they don't fit the rest
of the face and it also explains why we
find this so disturbing so why can't we
read people's expressions upside down
our superior temporal sulcus doesn't
recognize ever having seen that kind of
expression before so when we see it we
get well creeped out
you
